speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hello, I’m one of the medicine residents. I understand you came in from dialysis because of pain and swelling in your left groin where your catheter is. Can you tell me when that pain started and how it’s changed over the last few days?

speaker: PATIENT
text: It started about three days ago. At first it was just sore, but then it got worse and I felt a hard bump near the catheter. Today after dialysis they said it looked hot and was draining pus. I’ve also felt chills, like I might have a fever, but when they checked it at home it wasn’t high.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Thank you. Any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, or pain when you pee?

speaker: PATIENT
text: No, I haven’t thrown up. No diarrhea when I came in, no cough or breathing problems, no chest pain, and I don’t make urine anymore because of my kidneys.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You have HIV and are on dialysis, correct? Are you taking any HIV medicines right now, or just the Bactrim and azithromycin to prevent infections?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yeah, I’ve got AIDS. They told me my CD4 was really low. I’ve been taking Bactrim and that big azithromycin pill once a week, but I haven’t been on the HIV meds for a while before this.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: On exam I see a very tender, warm, firm area just above the left femoral catheter, but I don’t see pus right now. Your vital signs are stable and your lungs and heart sound okay. Your initial labs show a low hemoglobin around 8, white count about 4, and your creatinine is elevated as expected with your kidney disease. Potassium is a bit low at 3.1, and phosphate is low at 1.5. We’re concerned about an infection of that catheter that could be in your bloodstream.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So that line is really infected? Is that why it hurts so much?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, that’s our concern. The dialysis unit already gave you doses of ceftazidime and vancomycin before you came here, and we’ve drawn blood cultures. We’re going to get an ultrasound of the leg veins to look for a clot and talk with interventional radiology and nephrology about removing that catheter after dialysis today and sending the tip for culture.

speaker: PATIENT
text: If you take that line out, how am I going to get dialysis?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’ll coordinate with the kidney doctors. The plan is to remove the infected left femoral catheter after you get dialysis today, then give you a few days without a line to clear the infection, and then place a new tunneled catheter, likely on the right side. During that time we’ll manage your fluids and labs closely.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, I’m scared but I understand. This pain is really bad though.

speaker: NURSE
text: I’m going to give you some IV Dilaudid for the groin pain as ordered, and we’ll keep checking your blood pressure and breathing. If the pain doesn’t improve, let me know.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you, it really hurts when I move my leg.

speaker: CONSULT
text: Hi, I’m from interventional radiology. We’ve reviewed your ultrasound, which didn’t show a clear clot in the left femoral or superficial femoral veins, though the study was limited because of your pain. We’re going to remove the tunneled hemodialysis catheter in your left groin now and send the tip for culture.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Will that make the infection go away?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Removing the infected catheter plus the IV antibiotics you’re getting gives you the best chance to clear the infection from your blood. We’ll do this under local anesthesia; you’ll feel some pressure but we’ll try to keep you comfortable.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright, just please don’t let it hurt too much.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’ve removed the left femoral tunneled dialysis catheter without complications. The tip has been sent for culture. A dressing is in place over the site. Let us know if you notice bleeding or increased swelling.

speaker: PATIENT
text: It’s sore, but I’m glad it’s out. What happens next?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your blood cultures and the catheter tip culture are pending. We’ve started you on IV vancomycin, and you already received gentamicin and ceftazidime earlier. We’ll be checking your vancomycin levels and kidney labs closely, especially since you’re on dialysis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I just feel tired and don’t feel like eating much.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: This morning your labs show your hemoglobin is still around 8, white count about 3.6, and your creatinine is 5.8 with BUN 21. Electrolytes look acceptable. Your vancomycin level is high at 33.6, so pharmacy will help us adjust the dosing around dialysis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Is that bad, that the antibiotic level is high?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: It just means we need to be careful with the dose so you don’t get side effects. Because you don’t make urine, the drug stays in your body longer, and dialysis helps clear it. We’ll time the doses after dialysis and keep checking levels.

speaker: NURSE
text: You’re going down for dialysis now. Since your old line was removed, they’ll be using temporary access as arranged by nephrology. We’ll continue your vancomycin after dialysis per the protocol.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I’m nervous without my usual line, but I know I need dialysis.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Your cultures are back. The catheter tip and wound culture from your left groin grew methicillin-resistant Staph aureus, MRSA. One of your blood cultures also grew the same organism, confirming bacteremia. The good news is your follow-up blood cultures have shown no growth so far.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So the infection was in my blood too? Is that why I’ve been feeling so wiped out?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes, that’s right. A bloodstream infection can make you feel very fatigued. We’ll continue IV vancomycin for a total of three weeks, given after your dialysis sessions, to fully treat the MRSA bacteremia and catheter infection.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Three weeks is a long time, but I’ll do what I have to.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from nephrology. Your phosphorus has been running low, around 1.5 to 1.6, so we’re going to hold your sevelamer for now. We’ll continue cinacalcet and your renal vitamins. We’ll also plan for a new tunneled dialysis catheter on the right side after a three-day line holiday.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, so I stop that big phosphate pill for now? And the new line will be on the other side?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Yes, we’re holding the phosphate binder. And tomorrow we’ll place a tunneled catheter in your right common femoral vein under imaging guidance so you can continue dialysis more comfortably.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I just hope this one doesn’t get infected too.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’ve just placed a right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter. The tip is in the right atrium and the line is ready for use. There were no immediate complications.

speaker: PATIENT
text: My right groin feels sore, but not as bad as the other side did.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’re going to get a transesophageal echocardiogram because of the MRSA in your blood, to look for any infection on the heart valves or on the new catheter tip.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s the test where they put a tube down my throat, right? Will I be asleep?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes, it’s the one with a small ultrasound probe in the esophagus. You’ll get sedation so you’re drowsy and comfortable, and we’ll monitor you closely.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from cardiology. Your first TEE showed a small atrial septal defect and that the dialysis catheter was actually crossing from the right atrium into the left atrium through that defect, with a small mobile mass on the catheter tip that likely represented thrombus. We started you on a heparin drip to anticoagulate you.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So the line went into the wrong side of my heart? Could that cause a stroke?

speaker: CONSULT
text: It was passing through a small hole between the upper chambers, and that’s why we were worried about clot and stroke risk. After 48 hours of heparin, a repeat TEE showed that the mass on the catheter tip had resolved. We then exchanged the catheter for a shorter one so the tip now sits in the upper inferior vena cava, away from the defect.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’m glad that clot is gone. Do I have to stay on blood thinners forever now?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Cardiology recommended long-term anticoagulation, especially since you have atrial fibrillation and kidney disease, but given concerns about medication adherence and your preference, we are not starting warfarin now. We’ll continue aspirin only.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Honestly, I don’t think I could keep up with all the blood tests for warfarin, so I’m okay with that.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You’ve started having frequent watery bowel movements since yesterday, and your stool test came back positive for C. difficile, a bacterial infection of the colon often triggered by antibiotics. We’re stopping the oral vancomycin we briefly used and have started you on oral metronidazole three times a day for 14 days.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That explains the diarrhea. Will this new antibiotic fix it?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, metronidazole is effective for mild to moderate C. diff. Keep taking it even if the diarrhea improves, and we’ll make sure you have enough pills to finish the 14-day course at home.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We also spoke with your HIV doctor. Given your very low CD4 count and high viral load, and after discussing goals of care with you, we’re restarting antiretroviral therapy: abacavir, atazanavir boosted with ritonavir, and emtricitabine. You’ll continue Bactrim and azithromycin for prophylaxis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s a lot of pills. I got confused before. How am I supposed to take them with dialysis?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’ll give you written instructions. For example, take emtricitabine after dialysis on Mondays and Fridays, and take the others once daily, ideally after dialysis as well. Your outpatient HIV doctor and pharmacist will review this with you again.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, if it’s written down and someone goes over it with me, I think I can manage.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your labs this morning show your hemoglobin is 7.7, hematocrit 24, white count 3.4, and platelets 244. Creatinine is 5.7, BUN 35, sodium 138, potassium 4.0, bicarbonate 27, and phosphate 3.4. These are stable for you, though you remain anemic and leukopenic.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I still feel tired, but not as bad as when I came in. The diarrhea is slowing down too.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: On exam today, your temperature is normal, blood pressure is about 98 over 65, heart rate 75, and you’re breathing comfortably on room air. Your right groin catheter site looks clean without redness or tenderness, and the left groin removal site is healing under the dressing. Your heart murmur we heard earlier has resolved, and your lungs are clear.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So does that mean I can go home soon?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes. You’re stable for discharge today. You’ll go home with visiting nurse services. You’ll continue dialysis on your usual schedule, and at each dialysis session you’ll receive IV vancomycin for a total of three weeks from when we started, to complete treatment for the MRSA bacteremia. You’ll also keep taking Flagyl for C. diff until the 14-day course is done, and continue your HIV medicines and prophylaxis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Will someone at dialysis know about the antibiotics and my new HIV meds?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, we’re sending detailed discharge paperwork to your dialysis center and your HIV clinic. The dialysis unit will have orders to give vancomycin after each session until the end date, and your follow-up appointments are arranged. If you get fever, chills, or drainage from the new catheter site, or if the diarrhea worsens, you should seek urgent care.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. Thank you all for taking care of me and explaining everything.
